description: From Middle English confessen, from Anglo-Norman confesser, from Old French confesser, from Latin confessus (Old French confés), past participle of cōnfiteor (“I confess, I admit”) from con- + fateor (“I admit”). Displaced Middle English andetten (“to confess, admit”) (from Old English andettan). Doublet of confiteor.

verbs.description: confess (third-person singular simple present confesses, present participle confessing, simple past and past participle confessed)

entries.meaning: To admit to the truth, particularly in the context of sins or crimes committed.
examples: I confess to spray-painting all over that mural!
I confess that I am a sinner.

entries.meaning: To acknowledge faith in; to profess belief in.
examples: Whosoever, therefore, shall confess me before men, him will I confess, also, before my Father which is in heaven.

entries.meaning: (religion) To unburden (oneself) of sins to God or a priest, in order to receive absolution.
examples: Our beautiful votary took an opportunity of confessing herself to this celebrated father.

entries.meaning: (religion) To hear or receive such a confession of sins from.
examples: He  […]  heard mass, and the prince, his son, with him, and the most part of his company were confessed.
